alerts.alert: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.name: Content Security Policy (CSP) Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Content Security Policy (CSP) is an added layer of security that helps to detect and mitigate certain types of attacks, including Cross Site Scripting (XSS) and data injection attacks. These attacks are used for everything from data theft to site defacement or distribution of malware. CSP provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to declare approved sources of content that browsers should be allowed to load on that page — covered types are JavaScript, CSS, HTML frames, fonts, images and embeddable objects such as Java applets, ActiveX, audio and video files.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Content-Security-Policy header.

alerts.name: Cookie without SameSite Attribute
alerts.desc: A cookie has been set without the SameSite attribute, which means that the cookie can be sent as a result of a 'cross-site' request. The SameSite attribute is an effective counter measure to cross-site request forgery, cross-site script inclusion, and timing attacks.
alerts.solution: Ensure that the SameSite attribute is set to either 'lax' or ideally 'strict' for all cookies.

alerts.name: Permissions Policy Header Not Set
alerts.desc: Permissions Policy Header is an added layer of security that helps to restrict from unauthorized access or usage of browser/client features by web resources. This policy ensures the user privacy by limiting or specifying the features of the browsers can be used by the web resources. Permissions Policy provides a set of standard HTTP headers that allow website owners to limit which features of browsers can be used by the page such as camera, microphone, location, full screen etc.
alerts.solution: Ensure that your web server, application server, load balancer, etc. is configured to set the Permissions-Policy header.

alerts.name: Timestamp Disclosure - Unix
alerts.desc: A timestamp was disclosed by the application/web server - Unix
alerts.solution: Manually confirm that the timestamp data is not sensitive, and that the data cannot be aggregated to disclose exploitable patterns.

alerts.alert: Charset Mismatch (Header Versus Meta Content-Type Charset)
alerts.name: Charset Mismatch (Header Versus Meta Content-Type Charset)
alerts.desc:
This check identifies responses where the HTTP Content-Type header declares a charset different from the charset defined by the body of the HTML or XML. When there's a charset mismatch between the HTTP header and content body Web browsers can be forced into an undesirable content-sniffing mode to determine the content's correct character set.

An attacker could manipulate content on the page to be interpreted in an encoding of their choice. For example, if an attacker can control content at the beginning of the page, they could inject script using UTF-7 encoded text and manipulate some browsers into interpreting that text.

instances.otherinfo: There was a charset mismatch between the HTTP Header and the META content-type encoding declarations: [UTF-8] and [iso-8859-1] do not match.

alerts.solution: Force UTF-8 for all text content in both the HTTP header and meta tags in HTML or encoding declarations in XML.
alerts.otherinfo: There was a charset mismatch between the HTTP Header and the META content-type encoding declarations: [UTF-8] and [iso-8859-1] do not match.

alerts.alert: Information Disclosure - Sensitive Information in URL
alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Sensitive Information in URL
alerts.desc: The request appeared to contain sensitive information leaked in the URL. This can violate PCI and most organizational compliance policies. You can configure the list of strings for this check to add or remove values specific to your environment.

alerts.name: Information Disclosure - Suspicious Comments
alerts.desc: The response appears to contain suspicious comments which may help an attacker. Note: Matches made within script blocks or files are against the entire content not only comments.

instances.otherinfo: The following pattern was used: \bSELECT\b and was detected 2 times, the first in the element starting with: "function reinitForm(a){suppressionTagStyle(a,"span","erreur");suppressionTagStyle(a,"p","erreur");modificationTagStyle(a,"input"", see evidence field for the suspicious comment/snippet.

alerts.solution: Remove all comments that return information that may help an attacker and fix any underlying problems they refer to.
alerts.otherinfo: The following pattern was used: \bSELECT\b and was detected in the element starting with: "

alerts.desc: The application appears to be a modern web application. If you need to explore it automatically then the Ajax Spider may well be more effective than the standard one.

instances.otherinfo: Links have been found that do not have traditional href attributes, which is an indication that this is a modern web application.

alerts.name: Non-Storable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are not storable by caching components such as proxy servers. If the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information, it may benefit from being stored and cached, to improve performance.
alerts.solution:
The content may be marked as storable by ensuring that the following conditions are satisfied:

The request method must be understood by the cache and defined as being cacheable ("GET", "HEAD", and "POST" are currently defined as cacheable)

The response status code must be understood by the cache (one of the 1XX, 2XX, 3XX, 4XX, or 5XX response classes are generally understood)

The "no-store" cache directive must not appear in the request or response header fields

For caching by "shared" caches such as "proxy" caches, the "private" response directive must not appear in the response

For caching by "shared" caches such as "proxy" caches, the "Authorization" header field must not appear in the request, unless the response explicitly allows it (using one of the "must-revalidate", "public", or "s-maxage" Cache-Control response directives)

In addition to the conditions above, at least one of the following conditions must also be satisfied by the response:

It must contain an "Expires" header field

It must contain a "max-age" response directive

For "shared" caches such as "proxy" caches, it must contain a "s-maxage" response directive

It must contain a "Cache Control Extension" that allows it to be cached

It must have a status code that is defined as cacheable by default (200, 203, 204, 206, 300, 301, 404, 405, 410, 414, 501).

alerts.name: Re-examine Cache-control Directives
alerts.desc: The cache-control header has not been set properly or is missing, allowing the browser and proxies to cache content. For static assets like css, js, or image files this might be intended, however, the resources should be reviewed to ensure that no sensitive content will be cached.
alerts.solution: For secure content, ensure the cache-control HTTP header is set with "no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate". If an asset should be cached consider setting the directives "public, max-age, immutable".

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Dest Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies how and where the data would be used. For instance, if the value is audio, then the requested resource must be audio data and not any other type of resource.
alerts.solution: Ensure that Sec-Fetch-Dest header is included in request headers.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Mode Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Allows to differentiate between requests for navigating between HTML pages and requests for loading resources like images, audio etc.
alerts.solution: Ensure that Sec-Fetch-Mode header is included in request headers.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-Site Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies the relationship between request initiator's origin and target's origin.
alerts.solution: Ensure that Sec-Fetch-Site header is included in request headers.

alerts.name: Sec-Fetch-User Header is Missing
alerts.desc: Specifies if a navigation request was initiated by a user.
alerts.solution: Ensure that Sec-Fetch-User header is included in user initiated requests.

alerts.name: Session Management Response Identified
alerts.desc: The given response has been identified as containing a session management token. The 'Other Info' field contains a set of header tokens that can be used in the Header Based Session Management Method. If the request is in a context which has a Session Management Method set to "Auto-Detect" then this rule will change the session management to use the tokens identified.

instances.otherinfo: cookie:JSESSIONID
cookie:JSESSIONID

alerts.solution: This is an informational alert rather than a vulnerability and so there is nothing to fix.

alerts.name: Storable and Cacheable Content
alerts.desc: The response contents are storable by caching components such as proxy servers, and may be retrieved directly from the cache, rather than from the origin server by the caching servers, in response to similar requests from other users. If the response data is sensitive, personal or user-specific, this may result in sensitive information being leaked. In some cases, this may even result in a user gaining complete control of the session of another user, depending on the configuration of the caching components in use in their environment. This is primarily an issue where "shared" caching servers such as "proxy" caches are configured on the local network. This configuration is typically found in corporate or educational environments, for instance.

instances.otherinfo: In the absence of an explicitly specified caching lifetime directive in the response, a liberal lifetime heuristic of 1 year was assumed. This is permitted by rfc7234.
In the absence of an explicitly specified caching lifetime directive in the response, a liberal lifetime heuristic of 1 year was assumed. This is permitted by rfc7234.
In the absence of an explicitly specified caching lifetime directive in the response, a liberal lifetime heuristic of 1 year was assumed. This is permitted by rfc7234.
In the absence of an explicitly specified caching lifetime directive in the response, a liberal lifetime heuristic of 1 year was assumed. This is permitted by rfc7234.
In the absence of an explicitly specified caching lifetime directive in the response, a liberal lifetime heuristic of 1 year was assumed. This is permitted by rfc7234.
In the absence of an explicitly specified caching lifetime directive in the response, a liberal lifetime heuristic of 1 year was assumed. This is permitted by rfc7234.

alerts.solution:
Validate that the response does not contain sensitive, personal or user-specific information. If it does, consider the use of the following HTTP response headers, to limit, or prevent the content being stored and retrieved from the cache by another user:

Cache-Control: no-cache, no-store, must-revalidate, private

Pragma: no-cache

Expires: 0

This configuration directs both HTTP 1.0 and HTTP 1.1 compliant caching servers to not store the response, and to not retrieve the response (without validation) from the cache, in response to a similar request.
alerts.otherinfo: In the absence of an explicitly specified caching lifetime directive in the response, a liberal lifetime heuristic of 1 year was assumed. This is permitted by rfc7234.

alerts.alert: User Controllable HTML Element Attribute (Potential XSS)
alerts.name: User Controllable HTML Element Attribute (Potential XSS)
alerts.desc: This check looks at user-supplied input in query string parameters and POST data to identify where certain HTML attribute values might be controlled. This provides hot-spot detection for XSS (cross-site scripting) that will require further review by a security analyst to determine exploitability.

instances.otherinfo:
User-controlled HTML attribute values were found. Try injecting special characters to see if XSS might be possible. The page at the following URL:

https://www.cadastre.gouv.fr/scpc/afficherPerteMotDePasse.do?CSRF_TOKEN=KXF7-VZY2-GHKL-PM4E-AA98-EXOW-IQ53-QMBR

appears to include user input in: 

a(n) [input] tag [value] attribute

CSRF_TOKEN=KXF7-VZY2-GHKL-PM4E-AA98-EXOW-IQ53-QMBR

kxf7-vzy2-ghkl-pm4e-aa98-exow-iq53-qmbr
